list_definition.definition: anything flat (eg a piece of paper, a carpet) rolled into the shape of a tube, wound round a tube etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: a roll of kitchen foil
a toilet roll.

list_definition.definition: a small piece of baked bread dough, used eg for sandwiches

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: a cheese roll.

list_definition.definition: an act of rolling

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Our dog loves a roll on the grass.

list_definition.definition: a ship’s action of rocking from side to side

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She said that the roll of the ship made her feel ill.

list_definition.definition: a long low sound

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: the roll of thunder.

list_definition.definition: a thick mass of flesh

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I’d like to get rid of these rolls of fat round my waist.

list_definition.definition: a series of quick beats (on a drum).
to move by turning over like a wheel or ball

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The coin/pencil rolled under the table
He rolled the ball towards the puppy
The ball rolled away.

list_definition.definition: to move on wheels, rollers etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The children rolled the cart up the hill, then let it roll back down again.

list_definition.definition: to form (a piece of paper, a carpet) into the shape of a tube by winding

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Help me to roll the carpet back.

list_definition.definition: (of a person or animal in a lying position) to turn over

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The doctor rolled the patient (over) on to his side
The dog rolled on to its back.

list_definition.definition: to shape (clay etc) into a ball or cylinder by turning it about between the hands

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He rolled the clay into a ball.

list_definition.definition: to cover with something by rolling

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: When the little girl’s dress caught fire, they rolled her in a blanket.

list_definition.definition: to make (something) flat or flatter by rolling something heavy over it

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The lawn needs rolling
Roll the pastry (out) into a rectangle about 5mm thick.

list_definition.definition: (of a ship) to rock from side to side while travelling forwards

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The storm made the ship roll.

list_definition.definition: to make a series of low sounds

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The thunder rolled
The drums rolled.

list_definition.definition: to move (one’s eyes) round in a circle to express fear, surprise etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She rolled her eyes in consternation.

list_definition.mean_english: đi du lịch bằng xe hơi
list_definition.definition: to travel in a car etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: We were rolling along merrily when a tyre burst.

list_definition.definition: (of waves, rivers etc) to move gently and steadily

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The waves rolled in to the shore.

list_definition.definition: (of time) to pass

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Months rolled by.

list_definition.definition: a list of names, eg of pupils in a school etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: There are nine hundred pupils on the roll.

For large fluid depths and small temperature differences only circular plan-form rolls were observed.

By sheer accident, an empty trolley, nobody aboard, is starting to roll down a certain track.
His flow was anisotropic in the form of steady periodically arranged two-dimensional rolls.
The swing process cannot be carried any further, and the rolling boundary method is applied.
The intervention group was a closed cohort group where no rolling admissions were allowed into the group after treatment had commenced.
